2. American Medical Association Member ,  2006 - present Stanford University School of Medicine PhD,  Developmental Bilogy, Diabetes Mellitus 2000  – 2007 Dissertation Abstract: 
 
Pancreatic ß-cells adapt to changing physiologic states marked by increased systemic insulin demand. However, the signal pathways that govern facultative proliferation and compensatory gene expression in ß-cells are not well understood. I demonstrated that calcineurin and its target Nuclear Factor of Activated T-cells (NFAT) control ß-cell proliferation and insulin production in vivo. Mice with ß-cell-specific conditional deletion of Calcineurin b1 (ßCnb1KO mice) developed age-dependent diabetes. In contrast, conditional activation of NFATc1 in adult ß-cells increased proliferation and ß-cell mass and directly stimulated expression of insulin and other ß-cell factors. Expression of activated NFATc1 in the ß-cells of ßCnb1KO mice rescued diabetes mellitus and restored serum insulin levels. Thus, loss- and gain-of-function studies show that calcineurin/NFAT signaling in vivo is crucial for maintaining growth and crucial endocrine functions of pancreatic ß-cells. Summary As a John S. Knight Journalism Fellow at Stanford University, one of 20 domestic and international fellows, I focus on how to improve media service and infrastructure in undeserved and low-income communities.  
 
I have been a professional journalist and writer for 23 years. I started my career in 1992 at The Tenderloin Times, a newspaper founded by homeless men in San Francisco's central city. Since then, and before joining The Press Democrat in 2001, my work included stints as a reporter and then the editor at the St. Helena Star weekly; a regular contributor to Wired Magazine; a contributing editor to Wine Business Monthly; and a contributor to The Sonoma County Independent, the San Diego Union Tribune, and Gauntlet Magazine, a journal devoted to free speech issues.  
 
In 2007 and 2008, I took a sabbatical and worked at National Public Radio member station KRCB in Sonoma County, where I was editorial coordinator for Voice of Youth, a teaching project focused mainly on at-risk youth. We produced stories for a bi-weekly, bilingual radio show, learned stuff about each other and had lots of fun. 
 
My work has been recognized with multiple prizes including the George Polk Regional Reporting award (shared), a Best of the West Explanatory Reporting award and two Associated Press Fairbanks Public Service awards.
